prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Angular resolution: we have chosen the maximum angular resolution at Band 8 to study the inner envelopes of Evolved stars. The maser features are point-like, and we estimate a largest angular scale of interest of 2" for thermal line/continuum structures.
Spectral resolution: we require high spectral resolution for the masers in order to spectrally resolve individual maser feature linewidths of about 2 km/s (these are blended to form the broader single-dish lineshape of about 10 to 20 km/s).
We deliberately put all the basebands in one sideband, as trying to use the other sideband as well (either as lower or upper sideband) put spectral windows into even worse regions of atmospheric transmission.
Sensitivity calculation: the masers can be very strong, but we want to make sure to detect weak, line-wing emission of strength about 1 Jy. We have therefore requested a 0.2 Jy/bm senstivity in approximately 0.2 km/s to make a 5sigma detection of the line-wing emission. We performed the sensitivity calculation for the 439 GHz water line, since this is both our weakest line of main interest and the one in the worst atmospheric transmission.

We performed the sensitivity calculation for the 439 GHz water line, since this is both our weakest line of main interest and the one in the worst atmospheric transmission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Using APEX we have been observing and modelling CO and water maser emission for evolved stars. Our work to date indicates that we can explain the observed CO and most of the water lines by adopting a constant mass loss rate. However, this model cannot reproduce the strong 437 GHz water maser line seen in, e.g., RS Vir. It is likely that the 437 GHz maser transition delineates the structure near the star where pulsation-driven shocks occur. We are proposing follow-up observations at ALMA in order to: (i) put limits on the locations of different masers in circumstellar envelopes; (ii) provide a more constrained description of the extent of the zone in cirumstellar envelopes affected by the shock; and (iii) feedback the information into our stellar models to determine the physical conditions in the shock zone and in the further-out zone where the shock fronts have been significantly damped.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Onsala Space Observatory, Chalmers University of Technology
